awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Smart Vehicle Platooning Built upon Real-Time Learning and Distributed Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging connected and autonomous vehicle (CAV) technologies offer great potentials to reduce traffic congestion and improve traffic efficiency. However, much of the CAV related work focuses on individual vehicles's safety, which compromises traffic efficiency when mixed traffic (CAVs and human-driven vehicles) are on the road interacting with each other. This project aims to study how a group of CAVs can respond to exogenous disturbances resulting from human-driven vehicles, lane change requests and abnormal traffic and cyber conditions through cooperative speed or acceleration control. The research will improve road safety and traffic efficiency of future transportation systems involving CAVs. This project will disseminate research and education outcomes to broader audiences, including under-represented college and K-12 students with a particular focus on minority students. 

The specific research objectives of this project are to develop vehicle platoon centered optimal, adaptive, and resilient vehicle platooning control under various normal or abnormal traffic and/or cyber conditions. The project will develop (a) advanced model predictive control integrating distributed optimization for optimal vehicle platooning control under normal traffic/cyber conditions; (b) mixed integer programming based model predictive control for optimal vehicle platooning control adaptive to lane change requests; (c) resilient vehicle platooning control integrating real-time learning and distributed optimization under abnormal traffic and/or cyber conditions.  The project will integrate the state of the art from multiple fields including traffic flows, control, optimization, learning, and distributed computation and will establish an interdisciplinary foundation for coordinated and automated vehicle platoon centered traffic control under complex real-world traffic conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Vehicle platooning (VP), which enables a group of connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) to drive safely at high speed with small spacing, has a great potential to increase traffic capacity and reduce congestion, emission, and fuel consumption. Different from existing vehicle-centered and responsive VP control (e.g., Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC)), the transformative research seeks to establish Smart Platoon-Centered Control (PCC) for CAV Driving to achieve improved stream performance. Along with the research activities, the project also wants to enhance leadership opportunities for female and minority students, broaden research and education opportunities for underrepresented students, and promote interdisciplinary research and career development among graduate students. The key outcomes over the project period 2019 - 2023 are summarized as follows.

Intellectual merit:

This project successfully established the scientific foundation (Figure 1) that transferred current main-stream vehicle-based platooning to platoon-centered optimal, adaptive, and resilient vehicle platooning to respond to a complex real-world traffic environment. The following highlighted the significant methodology contributions.

(1)    Modeling: Introduced the PCC to the vehicle platooning control. It considers each platoon rather than a single vehicle as a unit and developed Model Predictive Control (MPC), such as MPC-NLP, MPC-MINLP, MPC-MIP, Hybrid MPCs, to systematically coordinate the driving maneuvers of CAVs in the platoon toward a better platoon-wise performance under various scenarios (see Figure 2), including car-following, lane change, pairing, merging, e-driving at urban intersections, (truck) platooning formation, etc. to better off entire traffic streams' performance. Moreover, we mathematically proved those MPC models' recursive feasibility, transmission feasibility, and stability to secure the functionality under different circumstances and disturbances theoretically. 

(2)    Online learning: The PCC factored in complicated mixed traffic flow environments involving CAVs and human-driven vehicles (HDVs). Various online learning algorithms integrating domain knowledge, such as curve matching and modified curve matching algorithms, were developed and verified to promptly capture HDV's temporal-spatial response delay according to real-time collected vehicle trajectories to make the PCC respond to HDV adaptively and accurately.

(3)    Solution: The PCC integrated distributed optimization and algorithms to design the MPC control laws, using the portable computation and communication capabilities of CAVs to enable intelligent and collective driving maneuvers in a self-organized CAV platoon. The algorithm design seamlessly integrates optimization, machine learning, statistics, and traffic flow theories to generate hybrid solutions factoring unique domain knowledge. Besides, we mathematically proved the convergence of each algorithm to ensure the quality and performance of their solutions. 

(4)    Extension: Further investigated Electric CAV charging on the move technology, which integrates the emerging technologies of battery-to-battery charging, CAV control, machine learning, and cloud computing to enable one EV to charge the other while both are on the move.   

The project opened a new research line in CAV platooning technology and built a solid foundation for coordinated (or cooperative) and automated driving under complex real-world traffic conditions. It will also shed light on automation technologies in future transportation infrastructure and advance interdisciplinary research involving transportation engineering, control and optimization, data analytics, and computer science.

Broader Impacts:

The research findings promoted the development of innovative CAV platooning technologies. The developed PCC has great potential to transfer the future traffic flow state and bring benefits in reducing traffic congestion, improving road safety and traffic efficiency, and enhancing mobility and environmental sustainability of intelligent transportation systems.

The research initiated a new research diagram of CAV platooning (i.e., PCC), leveraging state-of-the-art interdisciplinary emerging technologies and methodologies. Thus, this project significantly promoted seamless collaboration among transportation engineering, control and optimization, learning, and distributed computation to fully exploit the potential of CAV technologies. Beyond transportation engineering, the research initiatives will shed light on other relevant domains, such as control, operations research, machine learning/artificial intelligence (AI), information, edge computing, etc, and promote transformative research development in broader areas. 

The research activities generated more than twelve journal research papers, all published in top-tier transportation journals such as Transportation Research Part B: Methodological, Transporation Science, and IEEE ITS, along with two more under review and many conference papers published/presented on major transportation national or international workshops and conferences such as TRB Annual Meetings, INFORMS Annual Meetings, ASCE International Conference on Transportation, and IEEE Intelligent Transporation System Conference.

The project partially funded four Ph.D. students. The PI and her students have presented the research findings in many government, industrial, and university seminars, workshops, and conferences. In particular, the PI made a webinar for high school students in Seattle, WA, for their programs on connecting (girls) with Professionals. The PI used the fresh cases of this project as examples in the classes she taught to explain how new technologies affect the transportation system on both the supply and demand sides. Those education and outreach activities combined with interdisciplinary studies provided students with a multidisciplinary study environment involving cutting-edge emerging technologies, which enlightened students' interest in pursuing an education or career in STEM.


Last Modified: 10/31/2023
Modified by: Lili Du
